item.title: Comment on Wednesday assorted links by JWatts
item.description:
Reply to Reason:

This has been a long standing tactic of The Left. Remember the Congressional baseball shooting? Of course not, it was hardly reported.

But it is "right wing extremists" that are a threat, of course.

Feel the raw power of The Left. Raw power. I dare you to resist.

"I love democracy" indeed.

It's not so much as not reporting the story, but a concerted effort to frame the stories in an extremely biased way.

Regarding the transgender person attacking a Christian school and committing multiple murders in Nashville, here are some headlines:

"The right exploits Nashville shooting to escalate anti-trans" - WP
"Details about the Nashville shooter's gender identity sow confusion and disinformation" - MSNBC
"Advocates fear an escalation of hate toward trans " - NPR
"Trans people already fighting for rights in Tennessee have a new fear in the wake of a tragedy " CBC
"Trans People Face Rhetoric and Disinformation After Shooting" - NBC News
"Anti-transgender sentiment follows Nashville shooting" - ABC News
"Trans activist calls Nashville school 'right-wing institution' day after mass shooting" - Fox

item.title: Comment on Wednesday assorted links by dms
item.description:
Reply to DF:

#3

> Sponsors of the law say its purpose — prohibiting access to TikTok if it’s not sold to an American entity — is to sever the short-video app’s links to China’s Communist Party. The reality is that the American government will likely end up banning TikTok, turning it off for 170 million American users.

And that should be victory for everyone saying that TikTok and the CCP are one and the same.

Frankly I am sick and tired of all these so-called experts who do not know or refuse to play by tit-for-tat. Every single American company operating in China is a JV or complies with China's data and censorship laws. Can't play by our rules, then GTFO, the CCP says. Well I cannot think of a more reasonable rule than a news platform that broadcasts to half of Americans cannot be owned by the CCP.

"Every single American company operating in China is a JV ..."

Sounds like the opposite of truth: "A large majority of new foreign investments in China are WFOEs [=wholly foreign owned enterprises], rather than JVs. As Chinese legal entities, WFOEs experience greater independence than ROs, are allowed exclusive control over carrying out business activities while abiding by Chinese law and are granted intellectual and technological rights." (https://www.export.gov/apex/article2?id=China-Establishing-an-Office)

"WFOE refers to a limited liability company that is 100% invested, owned by foreign investors, and independently operated. Almost 60% of foreign-owned companies are WFOEs, making it the most adopted business type. Famous multinational companies such as Apple, Amazon, Oracle, and General Electric are all examples of WFOEs." (https://arc-group.com/china-company-setup/)

item.title: Comment on Wednesday assorted links by OutHere
item.description:
Reply to OutHere:

Okay. Great for you. I'm more worried about misinformation from adversaries. The trash they post on social media and other platforms here leads to a lot of division in this country.

You should take up WMD Iraq with Bush and co before you soil your diaper over CNN and the apparent corrupt NYT.

And I think your last question or point is too ridiculous to argue. Who said human to human transmission was impossible? We started locking down pretty quickly after it arrived because of just that - that it was highly contagious

Is CNN and NYT your definition of MSM by the way? Fox News just angels through it all going back to the Iraq war?

item.title: Comment on Santa Marta (Colombia) and birdwatching bleg by Moral Panic
item.description:
If you are new to birds, consider one of the phone apps that listens to bird sounds and identifies the bird. That can be fun and informative, even in a basic suburban environment sitting outside, let alone a totally new place. Or maybe you are far beyond such a thing.

item.title: Comment on Santa Marta (Colombia) and birdwatching bleg by Sean Crockett
item.description:
A good local guide will triple the number of species you observe, even if you're an experienced birder but relatively new to the birds of the area. They will also give you the best shot at rarities high on your priority list, and of course they can also be a useful window into local food. I have one of the great bird guides in all of South America. When I want to do a bird photography trip, I give him ideas and then he assembles the itinerary.

item.title: Comment on The Screwworm by rayward
item.description:
Hookworms and tapeworms were a big deal down here when I was a child. As for hookworms, they typically infected someone walking barefoot in soil contaminated with the hookworm eggs. Adults would check children's feet for the telltale hook. I don't remember ever being infected by a hookworm, but several of my friends were. My grandmother would have a fit if we went outside without shoes. Tapeworms typically infect someone from eating undercooked meat. The common explanation for a skinny person who ate a lot was that he had a tapeworm. The home remedy for removing a tapeworm can't be mentioned here at this blog. Robert Kennedy Jr. attributes the worm in his brain to eating undercooked pork. Kennedy ate the undercooked pork not the worm. I recall fancy restaurants serving steak tartare (chopped raw beef, seasoned with egg yolk, capers, salt, and spices). It's not exactly raw because it's marinated, but really. Restaurants no longer serve steak tartare, not for fear of liability to customers but the absence of demand for the dish.

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/05/the-screwworm.html?commentID=160757694

item.title: Comment on The Screwworm by rayward
item.description:
Reply to rayward:

Hookworms and tapeworms were a big deal down here when I was a child. As for hookworms, they typically infected someone walking barefoot in soil contaminated with the hookworm eggs. Adults would check children's feet for the telltale hook. I don't remember ever being infected by a hookworm, but several of my friends were. My grandmother would have a fit if we went outside without shoes. Tapeworms typically infect someone from eating undercooked meat. The common explanation for a skinny person who ate a lot was that he had a tapeworm. The home remedy for removing a tapeworm can't be mentioned here at this blog. Robert Kennedy Jr. attributes the worm in his brain to eating undercooked pork. Kennedy ate the undercooked pork not the worm. I recall fancy restaurants serving steak tartare (chopped raw beef, seasoned with egg yolk, capers, salt, and spices). It's not exactly raw because it's marinated, but really. Restaurants no longer serve steak tartare, not for fear of liability to customers but the absence of demand for the dish.

I should mention H5N1 bird flu which is infecting dairy cows (don't drink raw milk!) across America and alarming public health officials. One article I read last week described pig farms as a Petri dish for the virus, and that we are in real trouble if the virus spreads to pigs. I don't care for pork myself. Worms, bird flu, I recommend going kosher.

item.title: Comment on Did Norwegian schools actually ban cell phones? by jay which is blue
item.description:
People should browse the graphs in the linked paper.

One thing that stands it is that, "post-ban" (whatever kind of ban it is), the range of measurements increases dramatically in every single measured variable. This strongly suggests a measurement effect on the outcome of the study - e.g., some aspect of measurement method was different in some way prior to the ban and following it.

Which, in my opnion, suggests that modest changes in any outcomes probably aren't meaningful.

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/05/did-norwegian-schools-actually-ban-cell-phones.html?commentID=160757720

item.title: Comment on Did Norwegian schools actually ban cell phones? by This debate leaves me cold
item.description:
Reply to yo:

Nah, he's just jealous that he didn't get to experience any videos of beheadings, or sexy Auschwitz selfies, in his youth.
https://www.afterbabel.com/p/degrading-effects-of-life-online

Though I have previously remarked that Tyler is acting like a zealous defender of the smart phone/social media in the same manner as the zealous defenders of alcohol in the comments here.

But Haidt is also being a bit silly with this example - "While in London, I learned about the “cat in a blender” video that circulated widely online last year. Months later, video experts concluded that the video had been digitally edited and the kitten was probably unharmed, but millions of children saw a graphic video of one of the most depraved and disturbing things a human being can do." It would appear that Haidt is old enough to remember the classic SNL Super Bass-o-matic skit. And equally old enough to forget about it.

Yes, some of Haidt's caveats regarding the Super Bass-o-matic skit do apply, but it was one of the most hilarious things a youngish teenage me had ever seen. And yes, depraved indeed.

item.title: Comment on Did Norwegian schools actually ban cell phones? by steve
item.description:
Reply to PD Shaw:

Also potentially greater effect in the U.S. where the baseline is students using smartphones during class. Do Norwegian students follow the rules more than Americans?

If you really believe that the phones are the sole source of all the mental health issues we think we are seeing then this effect is smaller than expected. School has an outsized influence in the lives of kids that goes beyond the hours they attend. They cant use them to initiate or accelerate conflicts during the time they are in school and dont have the distraction. If you think phones are only part of the problem then I think the results are in line with expectations. A small improvement in grades and a smaller change or no change in mental health.

Even without this study I, and I think most parents, would have supported banning phones at school. There is an obvious cost in distraction if nothing else and close to zero benefit. Even a small improvement would be worthwhile against the near zero benefits of phones at school, I just dont think we should expect to see much of a change in other issues.

Steve
